links.displaytext: Your Turn - Perform a Risk Assessment

search.Text: start  topic    start  topic    start  topic personal safety and the safety of others must take priority over all other activities. safety maintain safety at an incident scene

safety at an incident scene  safety inherent dangers exist in any workplace. some workplaces, such as incident scenes, are more dangerous than others and it can be difficult to control the hazards. in these environments, personal safety must take priority over all other activities. the safety first approach (spadra) when working at an incident, you must avoid putting yourself at risk. by adopting the principle of the safe person approach (spa) and using the dynamic risk assessment (dra) process you can minimise the risk of injury to self and others.

the safe person approach (spa) safety there are two components to managing safety during an emergency. the first component is the safe person approach (spa) there are two elements to the safe person approach. these are: responsibility the organisation has to its personnel; and responsibility that each individual has to the organisation, themselves and those around them.  organisational responsibilities personal responsibilities click on the question marks below, to find out more

dynamic risk assessment (dra) safety the second component of managing safety during an emergency is the dynamic risk assessment (dra) dynamic risk assessment (dra) is a continuous assessment and control of risk in the rapidly changing circumstances of an operational incident.  unlike normal workplaces, the fireground often presents situations where risks are greater than normal due to the fact that emergency operations can be dynamic and unpredictable. the dra process involves six steps used as a guide to the identification, assessment and control of risks. these steps will be further explained on the next screen
understanding the dra safety

risk assessment matrix safety the risk assessment matrix combines the level of risk and the consequence into a single table. it is a useful tool for assessing the level of risk associated with your planned actions (step 3 of the dra).  it will help you to decide the control actions that should be considered and whether an alternative plan of action is needed (step 4 of the dra).

risk assessment matrix - likelihood safety likelihood is about how sure we are that a risk event will happen. likelihood, on its own, is not sufficient to assess the overall level of risk. so we also need to consider consequence that might result from each of likelihood descriptors.
risk assessment matrix - consequence safety consequence is about the effect or outcome that the risk event can have on personnel or property.

risk assessment matrix  level of risk safety level of risk is a measure derived from the likelihood of a risk event happening and the consequence that would result from that event.  the level of risk will determine the actions that should be taken.  example: a likelihood of: very likely  + a consequence of: catastrophic = extreme:   do not proceed/alternate tactics required
dra in action  worked example dynamic risk assessment you are required to report to a forward staging area, whilst traveling along a  major road you are confronted with this scene:

step 1: evaluate the situation dra in action: worked example  your task is to get to the staging area. there is fire along the roadside. there could be smoke, radiant heat, traffic, falling trees, damaged bridges, blocked roads, etc.
step 2: select dra in action: worked example  you need to get to the staging area  you ask the fire appliance crew to escort you though to the staging area along this road.

step 3: assess dra in action: worked example  you assess your risks of doing  as: could get burnt by fire might have a collision due to limited visibilityin smoke might be injured if hit by falling trees
step 4: decide dra in action: worked example  is this plan safe?  does the benefit outweigh the risk? you use the risk assessment matrix to decide

step 4: decide (risk assessment matrix) dra in action: worked example burnt by fire collisions with vehicles or objects hit by falling trees or objects you have assessed your plan as: extreme:  do not proceed your plan will need to be modified

step 5: modify dra in action: worked example how can you modify the plan to minimise risk? take another route. get information about fire conditions. use headlights / warning lights for visibility. ensure everyone has correct ppc/ppe.  can i make the task safer? return to step 3: assess, to assess the new plan
step 3 (revisited): assess the modified plan dra in action: worked example  assess the risks of your modified plan: it may take longer to get there. you may encounter roadclosures.

step 4 (revisited): decide on your modified plan dra in action: worked example take longer to get to staging area get stuck at a road block  you have assessed your newplan as: medium:  normal procedures should suffice your new plan does not need to be modified and you can jump to step 6

step 6: proceed dra in action: worked example  as your proceed, continue to monitor the situation: what is changing? what do i need to re-evaluate? are our goals understood? have responsibilities been clearly allocated? are safety controls clearly understood?

personal protective clothing & equipment safety you must be attired with the appropriate ppc/pe for the task being performed before entering the fire/incident ground.  only perform tasks when ppc and pe being worn matches the risk environment. wear ppc and pe during training. the ensemble is to be appropriate to the training.

bushfire protective clothing ensemble safety you must be attired with the appropriate ppc/pe for the task being performed before entering the fire/incident ground.  bushfire ppe should be worn to protect yourself from hazards if you are attending the following incident types:  grass fires; scrub fires; forest fires; plantation fires; car fires; motor vehicle accidents; gas leaks;  and structural fires  external defensive structural attack only.  wildfire helmet smoke goggles & p2 filter proban cotton overalls,  or 2 piece coat & trouser wildfire gloves wildfire boots (level 1 or 2)

structural protective clothing ensemble safety you must be attired with the appropriate ppc/pe for the task being performed before entering the fire/incident ground.  structural ppc should be worn to protect yourself from hazards if you are undertaking offensive structural attack.   note: breathing apparatus, splash suits and gas suits shall be worn by operational personnel wherever the incident controller deems the risk warrants such protection.  structural helmet structural turnout coat alglove firepro  (structural gloves) structural over trousers structural boot (level 2) or hazmat boot (level 3)

non-operational ppc safety you must be attired with the appropriate ppc/pe for the task being performed before entering the fire/incident ground. this will be stipulated by your role and be appropriate to the hazards you will face, whilst undertaking the task. this could include:  hat, long sleeves and pants to protect against sunburn hearing protection eye protection helmets for head protection enclosed footwear high visibility vests and garments tabbards  to identify role

bushfire protective clothing ensemble safety label the diagram.  drag the protection descriptors on the right of the screen and drop on the relevant ppc item. once you are happy with your choices, hit the submit button, lower.  falling objects falling objects falling objects sharp objects and hot surfaces sharp objects and hot surfaces sharp objects and hot surfaces ash and airborne particles ash and airborne particles ash and airborne particles radiant heat and lacerations radiant heat and lacerations radiant heat and lacerations chemicals, heat, ankle protection chemicals, heat, ankle protection chemicals, heat, ankle protection

heat related illness and hydration safety firefighters and other personel at incidents regularly confront the problems of working in heat, the effects of which may include:   heat stress  heat exhaustion hyponatremia (low levels  of sodium & electrolytes) premature fatigue  poor decision making (which can lead to accidents)    heat stroke

effects of heat safety cfa has produced the effects of heat brochure that provides ready advice on how to prepare and protect yourself against the effects of heat.  it covers: hard work and heat preparation and pre-hydration electrolytes heat illness protective clothing  download the  effects of heat brochure download the  effects of heat brochure download the  effects of heat brochure download the  effects of heat brochure

maintaining safety safety maintaining safety is essential during all fireground activities.  this section provides information that will help keep you and others safe. over the next screens, you will be introduced to two systems to maintain safety at the fireground: laces watchout

laces safety in some emergencies, as conditions change, firefighters rely on the use of safety zones and timely use of escape routes for safety. in these situations laces provides a system to maintain safety.   laces is used where there is a risk of burnover, of entrapment, or of a weather change increasing tree hazard.  click on each image below to reveal more. l l l l l l a a a a a a c c c c c c e e e e e e s s s s s s

watchout safety watchout is an acronym used to remind firefighters of potential dangers to their safety and to give advice on safe work practices.   understanding the meaning of the acronym will help you perform a more comprehensive risk assessment. click on each picture to reveal more  w  w  w  w  w  w  a  a  a  a  a  a  t  t  t  t  t  t  c  c  c  c  c  c  h  h  h  h  h  h  o  o  o  o  o  o  u  u  u  u  u  u  t  t  t  t  t  t

red flag warning safety a red flag warning is issued when there is a significant change to any critical information that may adversely affect the safety of personnel.  this can include: weather conditions; incident conditions and/ or behaviour; equipment availability; communications arrangements; access. further information is found in jsop3.11  download jsop.311 download jsop.311 download jsop.311 download jsop.311

incidents and near misses safety if you have an incident or near miss, you must report this to your supervisor.  a supervisor is your crew leader (operational staff) or escort/fireline contact (non-operational staff)   details should be recorded on the relevant agencys incident report form in accordance with the agencys process. these documents should be handed to the staging area manager or other designated person nominated by the incident controller.

entrapment & suvival safety your first priority is to avoid being placed in a life threatening situation.  however, you must always have a contingency plan to prepare for the possibility of entrapment when working or traveling in a bushfire situation. the following screens will take you through a series of entrapment situations, providing vital advice.

survival on foot entrapment & survival do not run blindly or attempt to outrun the fire uphill. do not attempt to cross through flames unless you can see the other side and they are low enough. try to move to the back of the fire, or across a slope out of the fires path. consider the location of burnt ground, streams, dams, bare or cultivated ground or large objects that will provide protection from radiant heat. as a last resort, clear a survival area by removing burning fuel and lying in depression, stumps holes, behind rocks, logs or ruts and lying face down. cover all exposed skin.

survival in a vehicle entrapment & survival if possible, park in the area of lowest fuel load. if possible, radio a mayday message.  turn on hazard lights and headlights.   leave engine running. close all windows and vents. a/c on recirculation directed to floor level. get down below window level and cover all exposed skin. once fire front has passed, move away from the vehicle to burnt or clear ground.
survival in a fire tanker   video entrapment & survival this video shows safety procedures for entrapment within a cfa appliance.

survival with heavy machinery entrapment & survival if threatened by a fire when working with heavy machinery  bulldozers, graders or similar equipment: if possible, radio a mayday message.  clear an area to mineral earth around the machine. turn on lights & leave the machine running. set park brake and lower attachments. shelter in the cabin or preferably seek refuge under the machine or behind the blade.

survival in a structure threatened by fire entrapment & survival outside the structure wear appropriate protective clothing & equipment. remain outside as long as practical to extinguish spotfires and wet down immediate area prior to the arrival of the fire front. use class a foam if available. remove or protect hazards such as lpg cylinders & firewood if time permits. secure possible ember entry points. take refuge on leeward sides of structures to protect from radiant heat.  outside the structure wear appropriate protective clothing & equipment. remain outside as long as practical to extinguish spotfires and wet down immediate area prior to the arrival of the fire front. use class a foam if available. remove or protect hazards such as lpg cylinders & firewood if time permits. secure possible ember entry points. take refuge on leeward sides of structures to protect from radiant heat.  inside the structure shut all windows and doors, close curtains, etc, if fitted. take fire extinguishers, knapsacks and hoselines (if possible) into the building. fill any sinks or other containers with water to use as a water source. patrol inside structure for spot fires or fire entry. remain calm & stay in contact with your crew and supervisor

traffic management points safety traffic management points (tmps) are temporary road closures established during an emergency to protect the safety of people, and vehicles, traveling into an area affected by emergency, such as a fire or flood.  tmps are set up to regulate the flow of traffic into an area where a emergency is occurring, or has the potential to occur. in addition to ensuring the safety of the public and emergency services personnel, tmps ensure emergency services personnel have priority access to combat or respond to an emergency.  download  the tmp information card download  the tmp information card download  the tmp information card download  the tmp information card

start  scenario    start  scenario    start  scenario in this scenario you will asked to identify risks, perform a dynamic risk assessment and perform a risk assessment matrix for each risk. scenario  perform a risk assessment safety

your turn  perform a risk assessment your turn your task is to make contact with the cfa commander, as identified by the red helmet.  this task is non-urgent. over the next screens, you will be asked to perform a dra of your task.  cfa commander

step 1  evaluate (drag and drop) your turn  perform a risk assessment drag the appropriate hazards onto the scene below.   once you are happy with your choices, hit the submit button, lower.  tripping hazard tripping hazard tripping hazard confined spaces confined spaces high temperature (radiant heat) high temperature (radiant heat) high temperature (radiant heat) chemical hazard (spilt fuel) chemical hazard (spilt fuel) chemical hazard (spilt fuel) electrical hazard (downed powerlines) electrical hazard (downed powerlines) electrical hazard (downed powerlines) laceration hazard laceration hazard laceration hazard biological hazard (blood & body fluids) biological hazard (blood & body fluids) biological hazard (blood & body fluids) crushing hazard crushing hazard crushing hazard falling object falling object falling object

approach the closest firefighter.  ask them to make contact with the cfa commander approach the closest firefighter.  ask them to make contact with the cfa commander approach the closest firefighter.  ask them to make contact with the cfa commander approach the closest firefighter.  ask them to make contact with the cfa commander approach the closest firefighter.  ask them to make contact with the cfa commander approach the closest firefighter.  ask them to make contact with the cfa commander walk around the perimeter of the scene and approach the commander from the rear. walk around the perimeter of the scene and approach the commander from the rear. walk around the perimeter of the scene and approach the commander from the rear. walk around the perimeter of the scene and approach the commander from the rear. walk around the perimeter of the scene and approach the commander from the rear. walk around the perimeter of the scene and approach the commander from the rear. walk directly through the incident scene, and make direct contact with the cfa commander walk directly through the incident scene, and make direct contact with the cfa commander walk directly through the incident scene, and make direct contact with the cfa commander walk directly through the incident scene, and make direct contact with the cfa commander walk directly through the incident scene, and make direct contact with the cfa commander walk directly through the incident scene, and make direct contact with the cfa commander step 2: plan your turn  perform a risk assessment based on the hazards you have identified, how will you  make contact with the cfa commander?  cfa commander

step 3 - risks your turn  perform a risk assessment by choosing to approach the closet firefighter, you have effectively  reduced the number of hazards to you.   what risks do these remaining hazards pose?  trip over & sustain fall injury trip over & sustain fall injury trip over & sustain fall injury risk of electrocution risk of electrocution exposure to infection exposure to infection exposure to infection exposure to chemicals/fumes exposure to chemicals/fumes exposure to chemicals/fumes cut by sharp body work cut by sharp body work cut by sharp body work

step 4  decide (tripping risk) your turn  perform a risk assessment what is your assessment of risk?  click on the risk rating to make your selection.  click on submit to receive feedback. complete the first assessment matrix, for the tripping risk.  risk 1: tripping over hose risk 1:  tripping over hose

step 4  decide (laceration risk) your turn  perform a risk assessment using the same approach, complete the second assessment matrix, for the laceration risk.  risk 1: tripping over hose risk 2:  laceration risk

step 4  decide (chemical contact) your turn  perform a risk assessment using the same approach, complete the third assessment matrix, for the chemical contact risk.  risk 1: tripping over hose risk 3:  chemical contact

yes.  proceed with the plan yes.  proceed with the plan yes.  proceed with the plan yes.  proceed with the plan yes.  proceed with the plan yes.  proceed with the plan no.  modify the plan no.  modify the plan no.  modify the plan no.  modify the plan no.  modify the plan no.  modify the plan step 4  decide (overall) your turn  perform a risk assessment based on your risk assessment, and recognising that this is a non-urgent task and you are not working under supervision, is your original plan still acceptable?

gain the attention the nearest firefighter, without entering the scene. gain the attention the nearest firefighter, without entering the scene. gain the attention the nearest firefighter, without entering the scene. gain the attention the nearest firefighter, without entering the scene. gain the attention the nearest firefighter, without entering the scene. gain the attention the nearest firefighter, without entering the scene. look up the cfa commanders mobile, and call him directly. look up the cfa commanders mobile, and call him directly. look up the cfa commanders mobile, and call him directly. look up the cfa commanders mobile, and call him directly. look up the cfa commanders mobile, and call him directly. look up the cfa commanders mobile, and call him directly. leave the scene, without completing your task. leave the scene, without completing your task. leave the scene, without completing your task. leave the scene, without completing your task. leave the scene, without completing your task. leave the scene, without completing your task. step 5 - modify your turn  perform a risk assessment given you have assessed your original plan as high risk, what can you do to make the task safer?

step 4  decide (plan 2 - tripping risk) your turn  perform a risk assessment what is your assessment of risk?  click on the risk rating to make your selection.  click on submit to receive feedback. complete the first assessment matrix, for the tripping risk.  risk 1: tripping over hose risk 1 (plan 2):  tripping over hose

step 4  decide (plan 2 - laceration risk) your turn  perform a risk assessment using the same approach, complete the second assessment matrix, for the laceration risk.  risk 1: tripping over hose risk 2 (plan 2):  laceration risk

step 4  decide (plan 2 - chemical contact) your turn  perform a risk assessment using the same approach, complete the third assessment matrix, for the chemical contact risk.  risk 1: tripping over hose risk 3 (plan 2):  chemical contact

step 6  decide (plan 2 - overall) your turn  perform a risk assessment  risk has been mitigated to a medium level and therefore normal procedures, with due care and diligence procedures should suffice you can now jump forward to step 6 and proceed with your plan.

step 6  proceed (plan 2) your turn  perform a risk assessment you have deemed that your revised plan is now effective at managing risks posed at this incident, as they relate to your task.  as you undertake this task, remember to monitor the situation:  are there any changes to the situation?is the incident escalating?  are hazards getting worse, rather than better? do i need to re-assess the hazards at this scene?are there additional hazards, that could cause myself or others harm? do i need to re-evaluate my plan?given the changing nature of the situation, do the controls i have implemented effectively manage my safety?

by completing this scenario, you have : identified risks performed a dynamic risk assessment completed a risk assessment matrix for each risk. this now concludes topic 2: safety congratulations.  scenario complete! safety

describe the weather conditions.  tick the two correct answers. day day day day day day night night night night night night raining raining raining raining raining raining overcast overcast overcast overcast overcast overcast
in total, how many patients were there? three. three. three. three. three. three. four. four. four. four. four. four. one. one. one. one. one. one. two. two. two. two. two. two.

which statement represents the status of these patients? two were ejected, one was trapped. two were ejected, one was trapped. two were ejected, one was trapped. two were ejected, one was trapped. two were ejected, one was trapped. two were ejected, one was trapped. three were ejected. three were ejected. three were ejected. three were ejected. three were ejected. three were ejected. one was ejected, two were trapped. one was ejected, two were trapped. one was ejected, two were trapped. one was ejected, two were trapped. one was ejected, two were trapped. one was ejected, two were trapped. three were trapped. three were trapped. three were trapped. three were trapped. three were trapped. three were trapped.

how was the scene secured?  tick the three correct answers. police tape. police tape. police tape. police tape. police tape. police tape. emergency vehicle to prevent access. emergency vehicle to prevent access. emergency vehicle to prevent access. emergency vehicle to prevent access. emergency vehicle to prevent access. emergency vehicle to prevent access. witches hats. witches hats. witches hats. witches hats. witches hats. witches hats. members of the public. members of the public. members of the public. members of the public. members of the public. members of the public.

where was debris present?  tick the two correct answers. in the culvert. in the culvert. in the culvert. in the culvert. in the culvert. in the culvert. road side. road side. road side. road side. road side. road side. on the road. on the road. on the road. on the road. on the road. on the road.

describe the vehicle. light green commodore. light green commodore. light green commodore. light green commodore. light green commodore. light green commodore. light green falcon. light green falcon. light green falcon. light green falcon. light green falcon. light green falcon. light blue commodore. light blue commodore. light blue commodore. light blue commodore. light blue commodore. light blue commodore. light blue falcon. light blue falcon. light blue falcon. light blue falcon. light blue falcon. light blue falcon.
what type of fuel? diesel. diesel. diesel. diesel. diesel. diesel. lpg. lpg. lpg. lpg. lpg. lpg. petrol. petrol. petrol. petrol. petrol. petrol.

what is the location? browns road, noble park north. browns road, noble park north. browns road, noble park north. browns road, noble park north. browns road, noble park north. browns road, noble park north. greens road, noble park south. greens road, noble park south. greens road, noble park south. greens road, noble park south. greens road, noble park south. greens road, noble park south. greens road, springvale north. greens road, springvale north. greens road, springvale north. greens road, springvale north. greens road, springvale north. greens road, springvale north. browns road, springvale south. browns road, springvale south. browns road, springvale south. browns road, springvale south. browns road, springvale south. browns road, springvale south.
what is the status of the fire? out. out. out. out. out. out. going well. going well. going well. going well. going well. going well. contained. contained. contained. contained. contained. contained.

where did the fire start? under the bonnet. under the bonnet. under the bonnet. under the bonnet. under the bonnet. under the bonnet. in the passenger compartment. in the passenger compartment. in the passenger compartment. in the passenger compartment. in the passenger compartment. in the passenger compartment. outside the vehicle. outside the vehicle. outside the vehicle. outside the vehicle. outside the vehicle. outside the vehicle. under the vehicle. under the vehicle. under the vehicle. under the vehicle. under the vehicle. under the vehicle.

what injuries did the driver sustain?  tick all that are true. burns to his hands burns to his hands burns to his hands burns to his hands burns to his hands burns to his hands smoke inhalation. smoke inhalation. smoke inhalation. smoke inhalation. smoke inhalation. smoke inhalation. burns to his torso. burns to his torso. burns to his torso. burns to his torso. burns to his torso. burns to his torso. lacerations to his hands. lacerations to his hands. lacerations to his hands. lacerations to his hands. lacerations to his hands. lacerations to his hands. chemical burns to his face. chemical burns to his face. chemical burns to his face. chemical burns to his face. chemical burns to his face. chemical burns to his face.

what should you do to attend to the drivers medical needs? tick all that are true. administer first aid. administer first aid. administer first aid. administer first aid. administer first aid. administer first aid. cal 000. cal 000. cal 000. cal 000. cal 000. cal 000. send him home. send him home. send him home. send him home. send him home. send him home. direct him to the local gp. direct him to the local gp. direct him to the local gp. direct him to the local gp. direct him to the local gp. direct him to the local gp. suggest that he takes himself to hospital. suggest that he takes himself to hospital. suggest that he takes himself to hospital. suggest that he takes himself to hospital. suggest that he takes himself to hospital. suggest that he takes himself to hospital.
who called 000? the driver. the driver. the driver. the driver. the driver. the driver. a witness. a witness. a witness. a witness. a witness. a witness.
